# Document Splitting

Discover the best practices and considerations for splitting data.

# Setup

## Python

::: {.cell execution_count=1}
``` {.python .cell-code}
from langchain.text_splitter import MarkdownHeaderTextSplitter
from langchain.text_splitter import TokenTextSplitter
from langchain.document_loaders import NotionDirectoryLoader
from langchain.text_splitter import CharacterTextSplitter
from langchain.document_loaders import PyPDFLoader
from langchain.text_splitter import RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter, CharacterTextSplitter
from dotenv import load_dotenv, find_dotenv
import os
import openai
# import sys

openai.api_key = os.environ['OPENAI_API_KEY']
```

# Recursive Splitting Details

## RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter {.smaller}

- `RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter` is recommended for generic text. 

::: {.cell execution_count=14}
``` {.python .cell-code}
some_text = """When writing documents, writers will use document structure to group content. \
This can convey to the reader, which idea's are related. For example, closely related ideas \
are in sentances. Similar ideas are in paragraphs. Paragraphs form a document. \n\n  \
Paragraphs are often delimited with a carriage return or two carriage returns. \
Carriage returns are the "backslash n" you see embedded in this string. \
Sentences have a period at the end, but also, have a space.\
and words are separated by space."""
```
:::


## Define splitter

::: {.cell execution_count=15}
``` {.python .cell-code}
c_splitter = CharacterTextSplitter(
    chunk_size=450,
    chunk_overlap=0,
    separator=' '
)
```
:::


. . .

::: {.cell execution_count=16}
``` {.python .cell-code}
r_splitter = RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter(
    chunk_size=450,
    chunk_overlap=0,
    separators=["\n\n", "\n", " ", ""]
)
```
:::


## Character Splitter output

::: {.cell execution_count=17}
``` {.python .cell-code}
c_splitter.split_text(some_text)
```
:::


- ['When writing documents, writers will use document structure to group content. This can convey to the reader, which idea\'s are related. For example, closely related ideas are in sentances. Similar ideas are in paragraphs. Paragraphs form a document. \n\n Paragraphs are often delimited with a carriage return or two carriage returns. Carriage returns are the "backslash n" you see embedded in this string. Sentences have a period at the end, but also,',
 'have a space.and words are separated by space.']

## Recursive Splitter output

::: {.cell execution_count=18}
``` {.python .cell-code}
r_splitter.split_text(some_text)
```
:::


- ["When writing documents, writers will use document structure to group content. This can convey to the reader, which idea's are related. For example, closely related ideas are in sentances. Similar ideas are in paragraphs. Paragraphs form a document.",
 'Paragraphs are often delimited with a carriage return or two carriage returns. Carriage returns are the "backslash n" you see embedded in this string. Sentences have a period at the end, but also, have a space.and words are separated by space.']

## Adapt splitter 1 {.smaller}

- Let's reduce the chunk size a bit and add a period to our separators:

``` {.python .cell-code}
r_splitter = RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter(

    chunk_overlap=0,
    separators=["\n\n", "\n", "\. ", " ", ""]
)
```
:::


. . .

::: {.cell execution_count=20}
``` {.python .cell-code}

```
:::

 '. For example, closely related ideas are in sentances. Similar ideas are in paragraphs. Paragraphs form a document.',
 'Paragraphs are often delimited with a carriage return or two carriage returns',
 '. Carriage returns are the "backslash n" you see embedded in this string',

## Adapt splitter 2 {.smaller}

::: {.cell execution_count=21}

# Token splitting

## Basics

- We can also split on token count explicity, if we want

- This can be useful because LLMs often have context windows designated in tokens

- Tokens are often ~4 characters.

# Context Aware Splitting with Markdown

## Basics

- Chunking aims to keep text with common context together.

- A text splitting often uses sentences or other delimiters to keep related text together but many documents (such as Markdown) have structure (headers) that can be explicitly used in splitting.

- We can use `MarkdownHeaderTextSplitter` to preserve header metadata in our chunks

## Markdown example

::: {.cell execution_count=42}
``` {.python .cell-code}
markdown_document = """# Title\n\n \
## Chapter 1\n\n \
Hi this is Jim\n\n Hi this is Joe\n\n \
### Section \n\n \
Hi this is Lance \n\n 
## Chapter 2\n\n \
Hi this is Molly"""
```
:::


## Headers to split on

::: {.cell execution_count=43}
``` {.python .cell-code}
headers_to_split_on = [
    ("#", "Header 1"),
    ("##", "Header 2"),
    ("###", "Header 3"),
]
```
:::


## MarkdownHeaderTextSplitter

::: {.cell execution_count=44}
``` {.python .cell-code}
markdown_splitter = MarkdownHeaderTextSplitter(
    headers_to_split_on=headers_to_split_on
)
```
:::


## Split text

::: {.cell execution_count=45}
``` {.python .cell-code}
md_header_splits = markdown_splitter.split_text(markdown_document)
```
:::


. . .

::: {.cell execution_count=46}
``` {.python .cell-code}
md_header_splits[0]
```
:::


- Document(page_content='Hi this is Jim  \nHi this is Joe', metadata={'Header 1': 'Title', 'Header 2': 'Chapter 1'})

. . .

::: {.cell execution_count=47}
``` {.python .cell-code}
md_header_splits[1]
```
:::


- Document(page_content='Hi this is Lance', metadata={'Header 1': 'Title', 'Header 2': 'Chapter 1', 'Header 3': 'Section'})
